displayed_text: Family Member: And tomorrow he’s, from the last night; tomorrow he’s scheduled to see a urologist uh uh they want to check him. Doctor: And would you get a flu shot? Family Member: Yes, he did while he was in the hospital. Doctor: So how are you feeling today? Patient: Fine. I feel pretty good the last seven days of the week or so. I moved around, worked on the computer. My wife won’t let me drive, so she drives me everywhere - Doctor: And do you have any pain? Patient: No. That is the question they keep asking me over and over; I really never have had pain. There was one time I had pain which is when I couldn’t urinate the second time when everything was blocked. That was and then that was pain was Patient: Right. Doctor: And you were in the hospital for seven days. Patient: Seven days. Yes and the numbers went from eight point six down to one point seven when it went out. Family Member: No, down to two point four. Patient: I’m sorry, yeah, to two point four, and then after that it was even more. So the last reading I had was Doctor: They didn’t put any tubes in your kidneys? They didn’t put inside your body?

Patient: Yeah. Well if you don’t mind, checking them out. Doctor: I’ll check with them. Patient: Yeah, because- Doctor: I know the guy at Cornell really well. Doing it is just an e-mail to say, hey, here’s my patient. How long would it take to get him on the trial? What’s the deal? And um- Patient: Okay. Doctor: He says we’re, we’ve got a waiting list out six months. Then you know we’re not going that way. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Terrific. Thank you. Doctor: So I’ll just let you know what the options are. Patient: Thank you. Appreciate it. Doctor: Alright?

Family Member: Okay. Alright. I didn’t mean not to take it home- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -but I meant if questions come up we could ask them. Doctor: Oh I see what you mean. Family Member: Let’s read it through in here and see if we have questions. I’m not asking you to sign it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay and then that way you – you know I’ll check back with you if you have questions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s a good idea. Just write them down though that way… Family Member: We’re not taking up a room? You want us to go back in the lobby? Doctor: If they need you to go to the lobby we’ll let you know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Alright and did I – yeah you got your copy of – well this is your CAT scan and a copy too.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, how do you make decisions? Huh, you know, I think it was, was it your daughter? Who was with you? Your wife? Patient: My niece. Niece. Doctor: Okay. Huh, huh, if she’s one of the people you make decisions with or other family members, huh, you can talk to them about what it is. Huh, but, huh, we’d love to have that conversation, huh, so we can go ahead, and I’ll print it for you today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll stop your abiraterone. Stay on the prednisone. I’ll check insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I’ll bring you back in a month no matter what. Huh, if you’re interested and you have insurance clearance, I may ask the nurse just to give you a call at home. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And say, hey, uh, it seems good. If you’re interested, you can come in this week and then we can get things started. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Then, we schedule that trip. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? And on that scan, if it looks like your cancer is expressing the PSMA, then we would start looking into whether we, uh, you know, then we can put you on the study. Because if it does- if your cancer cells are not expressing that antigen, I wouldn’t even bother going that way because what’s the point? Patient: Right. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Now, even after you get enrolled on it, though, there is a one in three chance that you may not get the actual treatment. Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it?

Patient: Well, I feel good. Doctor: Okay. We’ll have to see what your PSA is but obviously last time it’s gone down, and I’m thrilled. Patient: Well, let’s hope it’s gone down. So we haven’t gotten it back? Doctor: Um hum. Not from today but we’ll call ya’. Family Member: Oh yeah. I need to give the nurse the new phone number. Doctor: Oh. Well holler to him. He’ll write it and pass it on to K___ too just in case. Patient: What’s the number? Doctor: Excellent. Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that again? I’m sorry. Family Member: Hum? Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that? Family Member: Yes. (Patient gives phone number.)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either. Patient: In my world. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: In truly in my world. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m I’m, give me two seconds Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: So the one is with Vitamin C. The one with the immune therapy. So I’m putting down an appointment for you to see me in a month. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You can check on my chart or you and Dr. G__ decide something earlier, or you need to see us earlier, the scans are made, you can see me earlier; that doesn’t mean I’m going to start you earlier. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you know if it’s sort of you would rather do chemo with us rather than closer to home or if one of these studies makes sense, then we will be available or just to check in to sort of see where you are with some of these decision processes. Vital signs Your my chart, you’re already hooked in. These are the medicines I think you’re taking. Patient: Now I go for -I go for pulmonology tests, I think it’s tomorrow, maybe Thursday. Thursday, and but I don’t see a pulmonologist until early March, second of March. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe Dr. G can get thing done Patient: Yeah, I don’t know. Doctor: Some of that might be based on the CAT scan and your tests if they’re you know really at normal or suggestive of something, then that may open doors to get into the lung doctor in a fast - Patient: I understand. Doctor: ah I don’t have any paperclips here. So there are two different numbers here, so J.

Patient: Right. Doctor: and things may change when you’re on the study and we have to sort of make these changes ourselves so it’s better if we just do it. Family Member: Yeah, I agree Healthcare Professional: He can’t see the pain clinic here? Doctor: He can see the pain clinic here but are you almost out of your Percocet? Patient: Yeah, I want to say I have maybe, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because the other thought is Dr. S____ is here today, right? Healthcare Professional: Yes? Doctor: We have our own pain person. So, that way Family Member: Yay Doctor: if we have to transition, you’re right here too. Ah hah. So, you don’t have to Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we have to check everything. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah. So there’s no sticking or biopsies but it’s a blood draw. And you have lots to spare. So don’t say, “Oh, my, God”. Doctor: “She can take this ten and that’s it. I’m rolling out of here.” No. You have lots, and lots, and lots of blood to donate. Okay? Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, there’s a, there’s a couple of trials that are in the works that might be specifically suited for you Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because of this mutation. Patient: So, we’re not, not doing standard of care. Doctor: Right.

Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: For that your records. Family Member: So, the copy we got in the mail, it might be the same thing. Healthcare Professional: It should be probably different. (pause) Doctor: And do you have a local pharmacy you use? Patient: Yeah, it’s Rite Aid F___. Doctor: Two r’s or one r in F___? Patient: Two. No, it’s just one. Doctor: And do you know the zip for F___? Patient: No. Family Member: Umm, two oh five oh, maybe? (pause) Doctor: F___ five - one five two zero R____.

Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And um the person running the trial is a baseball fan so he has the Oriole trial. Doctor: We call it the Oriole trial. And um basically I will give this consent form and you can take it home to read through. Uh um, ORIOLE basically stands for for observation versus stereotactic radiation therapy for all metastatic prostate cancer. Um, the word means few. Like . And what does metastatic prostate cancer mean a few metastases, so it means few Patient: Um, hmm. Doctor: - you are eligible for this type of therapy for this trial. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So in this trial, the ORIOLE part is defined as having three or fewer.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. I hope that’s true. But my experience with these really expensive drugs is you’re going to get billed. Patient: Right. I was thinking the same thing. Doctor: Okay? So they will ask you then at our pharmacy, well, can you afford that amount of money, and if you can’t, so they will work to see if there’s grants to see whether they can, the drug companies who make these drugs, can cover the cost that you can’t cover. Okay? But you have to have Medicare D and all these other things. So it can take a little bit while depending on if they have it. And again, they’re going to do a wallet check to see how much you make to see what they think you can cover. Patient: Well, I’m working. Family Member: Well, right. Doctor: That, that’s just the rules that they’re going to go through.
